message_1: What is the probability of a Higgs boson decaying into a tau lepton and a muon, violating lepton flavor conservation in the process, based on the theoretical framework of the Standard Model of high-energy physics?
message_2:
In the Standard Model of particle physics, lepton flavor conservation is a fundamental principle. This means that the total lepton number for each lepton family (electron, muon, and tau) is conserved in any interaction. 

When a Higgs boson decays, it must conserve lepton flavor. Therefore, it cannot decay into a tau lepton and a muon simultaneously, as this would violate lepton flavor conservation. Consequently, the probability of a Higgs boson decaying into a tau lepton and a muon within the framework of the Standard Model is zero.
